awd_titl_txt: Study of Limiting Methods for Computation of Conservation Laws and Other Hyperbolic Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Many natural systems are modeled by differential equations of so-called hyperbolic type. For example, models used for weather forecasting, aircraft design, and study of ocean currents and biofluids are all hyperbolic differential equations. This research project concerns the development of techniques to approximate the solutions of hyperbolic differential equations. More precisely, the project continues the development of numerical methods for hyperbolic equations with non-smooth solutions (such as is the case when the terms appearing in the model itself are subject to the influence of non-smoothness; say, because of non-smooth boundaries, or interfaces). In such cases, effective methods must be able to remove approximation artifacts introduced by the non-smoothness, while maintaining as much as possible a behavior close to that of the underlying expected true solution. The impact of the project on applied domains in the sciences and engineering will be in introducing techniques to guarantee more accurate and efficient solutions based on numerical methods. Additional broader impacts include mentoring and collaborating with a graduate student and disseminating the research findings to the larger scientific community through seminars and public lectures. 

The project studies numerical methods for hyperbolic differential equations, in particular for problems that do not have smooth solutions, where accurate computations largely depend on nonlinear limiting methods. The PI will develop several techniques to improve existing numerical methods and also to develop new methods. One goal of the project is the development of new limiting methods for the "back and forth error compensation and correction method." A second goal of the project is to improve on the Courant-Friedrichs-Lewy (CFL) numbers of Runge-Kutta discontinuous Galerkin methods for hyperbolic conservation laws. Here, the main idea of the PI and collaborators is to use extra conservation constraints as penalty for the variational energy functional, and thereby achieve CFL numbers several times larger without increasing the complexity or reducing order of accuracy.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The PI and his Ph.D students apply BFECC to solving Maxwell's equations and have achieved major success !  This new finite difference method is simple to code, 2nd order accurate, doesn't use a staggered grid, can
be easily formulated on irregular meshes. The first result has been published in J. Comput. Phys. online, and extensions to scattering around perfect electric conductors and other objects, and to acoustic waves are being developed, using the level set method for computing boundary values to high order of accuracy. There will be a series of exciting new results originated from this approach.

The PI collaborated with S. Ashwin Renganathan and Dimitri N. Mavris (AE, Gatech) to develop a Koopman-POD-DEIM based approach to non-intrusive projection based reduced order modeling with black-box high-fidelity models.
This work has been published in AIAA journal.

The PI and his collaborators Prof. Yuan Liu (Wichita State U), Huijing Du(UNL) and Zhiliang Xu (Notre Dame) have extended the constant-subtraction technique for shallow water equation (supported by NSF, published in J Sci Comput, 2015) to DG methods on triangular meshes, and verified that the remainder modification for HR limiting won't hurt the order of accuracy in these meshes if the solution is smooth. The work has been published in J Sci Comput.

The PI is collaborating with his colleagues in school of math, Sung Ha kang and Wenjing Liao to develop a PDE identification method using a set of given solution data. A time evolution technique has been developed to eliminate
redundant terms with limited amount of data. This work has been published in J Sci Comput.   With additional collaboration from a previous student and postdoc, further development in 2D has also been done, a denoising technique and another method for eliminating redundancy have been developed. This work has been accepted by SIAM J. Sci. Comput.

The PI and his collaborators Haoxiang Huang (ME) and Vigor Yang (AE) recently have found a very efficient neural network method for capturing shocks sharply. This work is a breakthrough and has been submitted to arXiv. It can be used for solving essentially all differential equations more efficiently!

Intellectual Merit.
The PI and his collaborators have developed a new finite difference framework for solving electromagnetic waves or acoustic waves on irregular meshes which are suitable for dealing with scattering around various objects. They also incorporate the level set method to develop a local second order boundary value extension technique for approximating various boundary conditions of the scattering problems. This framework is also ideal for computing inputs of the novel neural network methods they have recently developed. They also found new efficient methods for identifying differential
equations from one given set of solution data, and for solving the shallow water equation.

Broader Impacts.
The developed finite difference methods are efficient and convenient to use in real applications with complicated boundaries and boundary conditions, such as antenna and aircraft design, cloaking, metal detection, medical ultrasound and metamaterial design, etc, which allows scientists and engineers with little training in numerical methods to easily adapt them to their own problems. These methods are also ideal for computing inputs for the neural network methods which were also initiated near the end of the project. The neural network methods are local solvers and able to predict shocks and other discontinuities in the solution much sharper than conventional methods, and can be applied to solving other differential equations more efficiently. They are particularly efficient in predicting a number of high-fidelity solutions corresponding to constant changing of experimental parameters, or for long time high fidelity computation of the solution. Therefore they are highly useful in scientific and engineering computing. The differential-equation-identifying techniques developed by the PI and his collaborators could be useful in discovering the underlying mechanism in biological, medical, physical and engineering applications.


Last Modified: 11/30/2021
Modified by: Yingjie Liu
